intro: Abarema waitzii, commonly known as the Waitz's evergreen acacia, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Brazil. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant is typically shrub-like, with woody stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to yellow. It is adapted to tropical and subtropical climates and is often found in moist, well-drained soils.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abarema waitzii is primarily native to Brazil. It is found in the states of Pará, Piauí, and Pernambuco. This species grows in tropical and subtropical regions, typically in moist forests and along riverbanks. It is adapted to humid climates with well-drained soils. The plant is part of the legume family and plays a role in local ecosystems.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abarema waitzii was mainly introduced to new habitats through human activities such as horticulture and landscaping. It is commonly found in disturbed areas, including roadsides and urban environments. This plant has adapted well to a variety of soil types and can thrive in both full sun and partial shade. Its rapid growth and ability to spread through seeds make it a potential invasive species in some regions. However, its distribution remains largely localized to areas where it has been intentionally or accidentally introduced.
